awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Low-cost Communication, Sensing, and Prediction for Precision Agriculture
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to develop low-cost, low-power, wireless sensor networks with long lifetimes for high density deployments in the field, primarily for precision agriculture. Existing solutions in the market consist of sensor modules with bulky batteries and repeaters driven by solar panels which drive up the cost.  These batteries and repeaters are infeasible for large-scale deployments. This project aims to provide sustainable solutions to increase the accuracy and efficiency of agricultural operations, while maximizing the crop yields and minimizing operational costs. The proposed sensor networks may also serve as a solution for military surveillance in the field, forest-fire prediction/mitigation, and smart highways.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project proposes the use of wake-up receivers for radiofrequency (RF) communications, while also using the RF communications for moisture sensing. This use of wake-up receivers and RF-based sensing brings down the size and cost of the nodes and enables mesh networking. The research objectives of the project include both evaluation of such a network and the determination of the feasibility and reliability of wireless sensor nodes deployed inside the soil across varying soil conditions and permittivity variations. The outcome of the experiments will be a set of specifications for integrated circuits (ICs) and networks required for a dense network deployment in precision agriculture.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
WiLO Networks goal is to provide on-demand sensing platform with sensor fusion for Industrial IoT. During Phase I, the major goals of the projects were to identify the right communication protocol for operating our proprietary radios and evaluating the requirements for such radio based sensor network in the field. A sample sensor network was deployed in a few plant beds and the performance of the sensor network was evaluated. This setup was used to develop and test the network protocol, algorithm and derive specifications for a low-cost low-power sensor network with long lifetime. The collected data was used to combine with weather data and data analysis algorithms were developed to forecast the future conditions of the soil on short term basis for informed irrigation as well as long term basis to predict yields.

Beyond Precision Agriculture, a broader set of market in speciality warehousing was identified, which included additional challenges of localizing the sensors inside the warehouse. Correspondingly, RF system architectures were developed for localization, and algorithms were evaluated for feasibility with such architectures. Additionally, IC design specifications were derived using the system requirements for use with the sensor node. For commercialization, external vendors were identified for ICs, antennas, battery and assembly to produce such sensors and gateways at low cost.

Additional challenges were identified through customer discoveries that translates to reliability studies that are required to be performed during Phase II. These studies are required to make sure the sensors and the gateway can sustain harsh environments. New challenges were identified for silicon design while deriving specifications, particularly towards radio design and maintaining a frequency reference. These challenges will be addressed during Phase II.


Last Modified: 05/30/2023
Modified by: Vivek Mangal
